issue.title: [WIP] Refactoring LINQ Query parsing.
Invalid SQL generated through UpdateWithOutput() for PostgreSQL and SQLite
issue.body:
### Describe your issue

I am trying to use the ```UpdateWithOutputAsync()``` / ```UpdateWithOutput()``` methods to update a table and retrieve information about the changed rows in a table.

For my test I am using a table called test, with two integer columns, named "a" and "b". I inserted two rows.

I repeated the test with SqlServer, PostGgres and SQLite.

I can query and update the rows for all three database kinds, but if I use the ```UpdateWithOutputAsync()``` / ```UpdateWithOutput()```, it generates invalid SQL for PostGres and SQLite. (It works for MS SQL.)

I also tried it with various tables, with similar results.

I would expect these methods to work for all supported database types.

#### PostGres exception:
Exception: Npgsql.PostgresException
Message  : 42P01: missing FROM-clause entry for table "DELETED"

POSITION: 74
   at Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.<ReadMessage>g__ReadMessageLong|233_0(NpgsqlConnector connector, Boolean async, DataRowLoadingMode dataRowLoadingMode, Boolean readingNotifications, Boolean isReadingPrependedMessage)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlDataReader.NextResult(Boolean async, Boolean isConsuming, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlDataReader.NextResult(Boolean async, Boolean isConsuming, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlDataReader.NextResult()
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteDataReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)

#### SQLite exception
Exception: System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteException
Message  : SQL logic error
no such column: DELETED.a
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLite3.Prepare(SQLiteConnection cnn, SQLiteCommand command, String strSql, SQLiteStatement previous, UInt32 timeoutMS, String& strRemain)
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteCommand.BuildNextCommand()
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataReader.NextResult()
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataReader..ctor(SQLiteCommand cmd, CommandBehavior behave)
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteDataReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)

### Steps to reproduce
Create a table with 2 int columns "a", "b" and insert any data

```SQL
CREATE TABLE [grid].[test](
	[a] [int] NULL,
	[b] [int] NULL
);

INSERT INTO [grid].[test] ([a],[b]) VALUES (1,2);
INSERT INTO [grid].[test] ([a],[b]) VALUES (2,6);
```

Map a class to the table in C#.
Query and  simple update works (tested for SqlServer, PostGres and SQLite).
When using the ```UpdateWithOutput()``` method, it works for SqlServer, but it fails for PostGres and SQLite.

Here is the generated SQL for all three of them. SQL2DB generates the DELETED pseudo table based code part for all, but it is not valid in SQLite and PostGres.

#### SqlServer (WORKS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  SqlServer.2019
DECLARE @i Int -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        [t1]
SET
        [t1].[b] = Coalesce([t1].[b], 0) + @i
OUTPUT
        [DELETED].[a],
        [DELETED].[b],
        [INSERTED].[a],
        [INSERTED].[b]
FROM
        [grid].[test] [t1]
```

#### PostGres (FAILS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  PostgreSQL.15 PostgreSQL
DECLARE @i Integer -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        grid.test
SET
        b = Coalesce(grid.test.b, 0) + :i
RETURNING
        "DELETED".a,
        "DELETED".b,
        grid.test.a,
        grid.test.b
```

#### SQLite (FAILS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  SQLite.Classic SQLite
DECLARE @i  -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        [test]
SET
        [b] = Coalesce([test].[b], 0) + @i
RETURNING
        [DELETED].[a],
        [DELETED].[b],
        [test].[a],
        [test].[b]
```

## C# test code

```c#
public class Test
{
    public int a { get; set; }
    public int? b { get; set; }
}

internal class Program
{
    static async Task Main(string[] args)
    {
        var db = new DataConnection( new DataOptions()
               .UsePostgreSQL("***** CONN STRING *****")); // MODIFY THIS TO SWITCH to SqlServre or SQLite
        var fluentMappings = new MappingSchema();

        var builder = new FluentMappingBuilder(fluentMappings);

        builder.Entity<Test>()
                        .HasTableName("test")
                        .HasSchemaName("grid")
                        .HasIdentity(t => t.a)
                        .HasPrimaryKey(t => t.a)
                        .Property(t => t.a).HasColumnName("a")
                        .Property(t => t.b).HasColumnName("b");

        var data = (from test in db.GetTable<Test>() select test).ToList();
        int i = 2;
       db.GetTable<Test>().AsUpdatable().Set(t => t.b, t => (t.b ?? 0) + i).Update() // WORKS
        var output = db.GetTable<Test>().AsUpdatable().Set(t => t.b, t => (t.b ?? 0) + i).UpdateWithOutput().ToList(); // FAILS
        var data2 = (from test in db.GetTable<Test>() select test).ToList();
    }
}
```

### Environment details

`Linq To DB` version: 5.3.2

Database (with version): 
PostGres - PostGres 15.1 / Npgsql 7.0.6 
SQLite - System.Data.Sqlite.Core 1.0.118
SqlServer - MS Sql Server Express 15.0.41 / Microsoft.Data.SqlClient 5.1.1

Operating system: Win 11 64bit

.NET Version: .net 6

comment.body: API documentation includes list of supported databases : https://github.com/linq2db/linq2db/blob/6bb5d8baaff795e44a38af7dc63019b38a346652/Source/LinqToDB/LinqExtensions.Update.cs#L788-L789

issue.title: Invalid SQL generated through UpdateWithOutput() for PostgreSQL and SQLite
issue.body:
### Describe your issue

I am trying to use the ```UpdateWithOutputAsync()``` / ```UpdateWithOutput()``` methods to update a table and retrieve information about the changed rows in a table.

For my test I am using a table called test, with two integer columns, named "a" and "b". I inserted two rows.

I also tried it with various tables, with similar results.

I would expect these methods to work for all supported database types.

#### PostGres exception:
Exception: Npgsql.PostgresException
Message  : 42P01: missing FROM-clause entry for table "DELETED"

POSITION: 74
   at Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.<ReadMessage>g__ReadMessageLong|233_0(NpgsqlConnector connector, Boolean async, DataRowLoadingMode dataRowLoadingMode, Boolean readingNotifications, Boolean isReadingPrependedMessage)

   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteDataReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)

#### SQLite exception
Exception: System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteException
Message  : SQL logic error
no such column: DELETED.a
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLite3.Prepare(SQLiteConnection cnn, SQLiteCommand command, String strSql, SQLiteStatement previous, UInt32 timeoutMS, String& strRemain)
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteCommand.BuildNextCommand()
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataReader.NextResult()
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataReader..ctor(SQLiteCommand cmd, CommandBehavior behave)
   at System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteCommand.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior behavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)
   at LinqToDB.Data.DataConnection.ExecuteDataReader(CommandBehavior commandBehavior)

### Steps to reproduce
Create a table with 2 int columns "a", "b" and insert any data

```SQL
CREATE TABLE [grid].[test](
	[a] [int] NULL,
	[b] [int] NULL
);

INSERT INTO [grid].[test] ([a],[b]) VALUES (1,2);
INSERT INTO [grid].[test] ([a],[b]) VALUES (2,6);
```

Map a class to the table in C#.
Query and  simple update works (tested for SqlServer, PostGres and SQLite).
When using the ```UpdateWithOutput()``` method, it works for SqlServer, but it fails for PostGres and SQLite.

Here is the generated SQL for all three of them. SQL2DB generates the DELETED pseudo table based code part for all, but it is not valid in SQLite and PostGres.

#### SqlServer (WORKS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  SqlServer.2019
DECLARE @i Int -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        [t1]
SET
        [t1].[b] = Coalesce([t1].[b], 0) + @i
OUTPUT
        [DELETED].[a],
        [DELETED].[b],
        [INSERTED].[a],
        [INSERTED].[b]

        [grid].[test] [t1]
```

#### PostGres (FAILS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  PostgreSQL.15 PostgreSQL
DECLARE @i Integer -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        grid.test
SET
        b = Coalesce(grid.test.b, 0) + :i
RETURNING
        "DELETED".a,
        "DELETED".b,
        grid.test.a,
        grid.test.b
```

#### SQLite (FAILS) - generated SQL

```SQL
--  SQLite.Classic SQLite
DECLARE @i  -- Int32
SET     @i = 2

UPDATE
        [test]
SET
        [b] = Coalesce([test].[b], 0) + @i
RETURNING
        [DELETED].[a],
        [DELETED].[b],
        [test].[a],
        [test].[b]
```

## C# test code

```c#
public class Test
{
    public int a { get; set; }
    public int? b { get; set; }
}

internal class Program
{
    static async Task Main(string[] args)
    {
        var db = new DataConnection( new DataOptions()
               .UsePostgreSQL("***** CONN STRING *****")); // MODIFY THIS TO SWITCH to SqlServre or SQLite
        var fluentMappings = new MappingSchema();

        var builder = new FluentMappingBuilder(fluentMappings);

        builder.Entity<Test>()
                        .HasTableName("test")
                        .HasSchemaName("grid")
                        .HasIdentity(t => t.a)
                        .HasPrimaryKey(t => t.a)
                        .Property(t => t.a).HasColumnName("a")
                        .Property(t => t.b).HasColumnName("b");

        var data = (from test in db.GetTable<Test>() select test).ToList();
        int i = 2;
       db.GetTable<Test>().AsUpdatable().Set(t => t.b, t => (t.b ?? 0) + i).Update() // WORKS
        var output = db.GetTable<Test>().AsUpdatable().Set(t => t.b, t => (t.b ?? 0) + i).UpdateWithOutput().ToList(); // FAILS
        var data2 = (from test in db.GetTable<Test>() select test).ToList();
    }
}
```

### Environment details

`Linq To DB` version: 5.3.2

Database (with version): 
PostGres - PostGres 15.1 / Npgsql 7.0.6 
SQLite - System.Data.Sqlite.Core 1.0.118
SqlServer - MS Sql Server Express 15.0.41 / Microsoft.Data.SqlClient 5.1.1

Operating system: Win 11 64bit

.NET Version: .net 6

comment.body:
That's expected. Old data not supported in returning clause for SQLite and PostgreSQL:
- https://www.sqlite.org/lang_returning.html : `For INSERT and UPDATE statements, references to columns in the table being modified refer to the value of that column after the change has been applied.`
- https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/dml-returning.html : `In an UPDATE, the data available to RETURNING is the new content of the modified row`

Create a table with 2 int columns "a", "b" and insert any data

```SQL

	[b] [int] NULL

INSERT INTO [grid].[test] ([a],[b]) VALUES (1,2);
```

##PostGres (FAILS) - generated SQL

```SQL
UPDATE

SET

RETURNING
```

```c#
    public int? b { get; set; }
}

internal class Program

    static async Task Main(string[] args)

        var builder = new FluentMappingBuilder(fluentMappings);

        builder.Entity<Test>()
                        .HasTableName("test")
                        .HasSchemaName("grid")
                        .HasIdentity(t => t.a)
                        .HasPrimaryKey(t => t.a)
```

comment.body: Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

issue.title: Improve `IAsyncEnumerable` usage
issue.body:
This PR does two things:
* Updates `InsertWithOutputAsync`, `UpdateWithOutputAsync`, and `DeleteWithOutputAsync` to return `IAsyncEnumerable` properly. This is a binary-compatible change, as the existing methods are kept. However, these methods are now marked with `[Obsolete]` to encourage source migration to the newer `IAsyncEnumerable` method. 
* Adds `QueryToAsyncEnumerable` in places where `QueryToArrayAsync` and `QueryToListAsync` are provided. This allows consumers to use `IAsyncEnumerable` if desired. No obsoletions are planned here, though consumers are allowed and encouraged to upgrade if the query has many rows. 
  > [!NOTE]
  > This change only applies to `NATIVE_ASYNC`.

## 💣 Breaking Change
* The new versions of `XxxWithOutputAsync` are not source compatible, so this is a v6.0 breaking change. Consumers will need to add `.ToListAsync()` or similar to address this change. This is to restore consistency between `InsertWithOutputAsync`/`UpdateWithOutputAsync`/`DeleteWithOutputAsync` with `MergeWithOutputAsync`; this consistency has been chosen to use the more flexible and modern approach.

comment.body: Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

issue.body:
This PR does two things:

* Adds `QueryToAsyncEnumerable` in places where `QueryToArrayAsync` and `QueryToListAsync` are provided. This allows consumers to use `IAsyncEnumerable` if desired. No obsoletions are planned here, though consumers are allowed and encouraged to upgrade if the query has many rows. 
  > [!NOTE]
  > This change only applies to `NATIVE_ASYNC`.

## 💣 Breaking Change
* The new versions of `XxxWithOutputAsync` are not source compatible, so this is a v6.0 breaking change. Consumers will need to add `.ToListAsync()` or similar to address this change. This is to restore consistency between `InsertWithOutputAsync`/`UpdateWithOutputAsync`/`DeleteWithOutputAsync` with `MergeWithOutputAsync`; this consistency has been chosen to use the more flexible and modern approach.

issue.title: Suggestion: BulkCopy with ON CONFLICT
issue.body:
I have a situation that is illustrated by following example:

```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "item"
(
  id INT NOT NULL,
  code VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT pk_item PRIMARY KEY (id)
);
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_item_code ON item USING btree (code);
```
Now I want to do a bulk insert by ignore duplicates on unique column "code" and it can be done like this:
```sql
INSERT INTO item(id,code)
VALUES (1,'1'),(2,'2'),(3,'2'),(4,'4')
ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING;
```
Existing BulkCopy method does not have an option to add ON CONFLICT at the end of statement.
Is it possible to add this option?

comment.body: It is possible. PR is welcome, as we probably will not have it on our list soon.

issue.title: `AddLinqToDBContext<TContext, TContextImplementation>` could register incorrect `DataOptions` type
issue.body:
See https://github.com/linq2db/linq2db/discussions/4324#discussioncomment-7382490

We should:
- use `DataOptions<TContextImplementation>`
- probe and register `DataOptions<TContext>` as fallback for backward compatibility if `DataOptions<TContextImplementation>` constructor missing

issue.title: [WIP] Refactoring LINQ Query parsing.

comment.body: Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

issue.title: [WIP] Refactoring LINQ Query parsing.
Suggestion: BulkCopy with ON CONFLICT
issue.body:
I have a situation that is illustrated by following example:

```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "item"
(
  id INT NOT NULL,
  code VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT pk_item PRIMARY KEY (id)
);
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_item_code ON item USING btree (code);
```
Now I want to do a bulk insert by ignore duplicates on unique column "code" and it can be done like this:
```sql
INSERT INTO item(id,code)
VALUES (1,'1'),(2,'2'),(3,'2'),(4,'4')
ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING;
```
Existing BulkCopy method does not have an option to add ON CONFLICT at the end of statement.
Is it possible to add this option?

comment.body: Fixed in #9d5bd15 (will be uploaded when possible)

comment.body:
> Perhaps we should do the opposite - hide the cancellation token from being exposed in the methods where we now have `[EnumeratorCancellation]` ? (By putting the implementation in a private method.)

Works for me. I'll take a look in a bit.

pull_request.body:
This PR does two things:
* Updates `InsertWithOutputAsync`, `UpdateWithOutputAsync`, and `DeleteWithOutputAsync` to return `IAsyncEnumerable` properly. This is a binary-compatible change, as the existing methods are kept. However, these methods are now marked with `[Obsolete]` to encourage source migration to the newer `IAsyncEnumerable` method. 
* Adds `QueryToAsyncEnumerable` in places where `QueryToArrayAsync` and `QueryToListAsync` are provided. This allows consumers to use `IAsyncEnumerable` if desired. No obsoletions are planned here, though consumers are allowed and encouraged to upgrade if the query has many rows. 
  > [!NOTE]
  > This change only applies to `NATIVE_ASYNC`.

## 💣 Breaking Change
* The new versions of `XxxWithOutputAsync` are not source compatible, so this is a v6.0 breaking change. Consumers will need to add `.ToListAsync()` or similar to address this change. This is to restore consistency between `InsertWithOutputAsync`/`UpdateWithOutputAsync`/`DeleteWithOutputAsync` with `MergeWithOutputAsync`; this consistency has been chosen to use the more flexible and modern approach.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -256,6 +256,34 @@ await using (rd.ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext))
 			}
 		}
 
+#if NATIVE_ASYNC
+		/// <summary>
+		/// Executes command asynchronously and apply provided action to each record, mapped using provided mapping function.
+		/// </summary>
+		/// <typeparam name="T">Result record type.</typeparam>
+		/// <param name="objectReader">Record mapping function from data reader.</param>
+		/// <param name="cancellationToken">Asynchronous operation cancellation token.</param>
+		/// <returns>Async sequence of records returned by the query.</returns>
+		public async IAsyncEnumerable<T> QueryToAsyncEnumerable<T>(Func<DbDataReader, T> objectReader, [EnumeratorCancellation] CancellationToken cancellationToken = default)
+		{
+			await DataConnection.EnsureConnectionAsync(cancellationToken).ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext);
+
+			InitCommand();
+
+			await using ((DataConnection.DataProvider.ExecuteScope(DataConnection) ?? EmptyIAsyncDisposable.Instance).ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext))
+			{
+#if NETSTANDARD2_1PLUS
+				var rd = await DataConnection.ExecuteDataReaderAsync(GetCommandBehavior(), cancellationToken).ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext);
+				await using (rd.ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext))
+#else
+				using (var rd = await DataConnection.ExecuteDataReaderAsync(GetCommandBehavior(), cancellationToken).ConfigureAwait(Configuration.ContinueOnCapturedContext))
+#endif
comment.body: Interesting, I didn't notice that. After reviewing, it looks like it's because `DataReaderWrapper` does not implement `IAsyncDisposable` in netfx, only in netcoreapp3.1+. Maybe @MaceWindu can explain?

pull_request.title: Improve `IAsyncEnumerable` usage
pull_request.body:
This PR does two things:
* Updates `InsertWithOutputAsync`, `UpdateWithOutputAsync`, and `DeleteWithOutputAsync` to return `IAsyncEnumerable` properly. This is a binary-compatible change, as the existing methods are kept. However, these methods are now marked with `[Obsolete]` to encourage source migration to the newer `IAsyncEnumerable` method. 
* Adds `QueryToAsyncEnumerable` in places where `QueryToArrayAsync` and `QueryToListAsync` are provided. This allows consumers to use `IAsyncEnumerable` if desired. No obsoletions are planned here, though consumers are allowed and encouraged to upgrade if the query has many rows. 
  > [!NOTE]
  > This change only applies to `NATIVE_ASYNC`.

## 💣 Breaking Change
* The new versions of `XxxWithOutputAsync` are not source compatible, so this is a v6.0 breaking change. Consumers will need to add `.ToListAsync()` or similar to address this change. This is to restore consistency between `InsertWithOutputAsync`/`UpdateWithOutputAsync`/`DeleteWithOutputAsync` with `MergeWithOutputAsync`; this consistency has been chosen to use the more flexible and modern approach.

comment.body:
For reference, EF Core’s AsAsyncEnumerable has no exposed cancellation token

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.entityframeworkcore.entityframeworkqueryableextensions.asasyncenumerable?view=efcore-7.0
